newsitem.title: CANADA: Bre-X Minerals climbs on rating upgrade.
newsitem.headline: Bre-X Minerals climbs on rating upgrade.

text.p: Shares in Bre-X Minerals Ltd rose on Friday after a U.S. investment firm upgraded its rating on the Calgary-based gold prospector.
Bre-X's stock rose 0.35 to 17.60 in afternoon turnover of 730,800 shares on the Toronto Stock Exchange. On Nasdaq, the stock was up 3/8 at 12-7/8 on 234,000 shares.
New York-based Lehman Brothers said earlier it raised Bre-X to outperform from neutral.

Lehman said the company's share price has fallen to attractive levels. The stock has been under pressure since Bre-X reached an agreement to develop the rich Busang gold field it discovered in Indonesia. Busang contains at least 71 million ounces of gold, valued at about US$25 billion.
"Although there are still uncertainties, we believe this stock will be at significantly higher levels a year from now," Lehman said in a report.
The agreement left Bre-X with 45 percent, New Orleans-based Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc with 15 percent, and the rest to the Indonesian government and to two Indonesian companies.
Since the deal was announced in mid-February, Bre-X's stock has fallen from around C$24 amid investor confusion over the company's stake in Busang.
Bre-X has said the company did not originally own 90 percent of the discovery and investors were mistaken to believe otherwise.
Bre-X and its partners are currently waiting for the Indonesian government to issue contracts of work (COW) before mine construction can begin.
"All else being the same, if Bre-X can resolve the Merukh issue and obtain its COWs, we will raise our rating to a buy," Lehman said.
Indonesian businessman Jusuf Merukh is suing Bre-X for US$2 billion in a Canadian court, alleging that his company was entitled to 30 percent of Busang.
